{{marriage|[[Jane Hajduk]]|2006}} | children = 2 | website = {{url|timallen.com}} }} '''Timothy Alan Dick'''{{cite web|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,1544253,00.html |title=Tim Allen Marries Longtime Girlfriend Jane Hajduk – Marriage, Tim Allen |publisher=People.com |date=October 9, 2006 |accessdate=December 13, 2011}} (born June 13, 1953), known professionally as '''Tim Allen''', is an American actor and comedian. He is known for playing [[List of Home Improvement characters|Tim "The Toolman" Taylor]] on the ABC sitcom ''[[Home Improvement (TV series)|Home Improvement]]'' (1991–1999). In 2011, he started appearing as [[Mike Baxter (Last Man Standing character)|Mike Baxter]] on the ABC sitcom ''[[Last Man Standing (U.S. TV series)|Last Man Standing]]'' (2011–2017). In 2018, [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]] picked up ''Last Man Standing'' for a seventh season.{{cite news|last1=McCarthy|first1=Tyler|title=Tim Allen shares first teaser for 'Last Man Standing' Season 7|url=http://www.foxnews.com/entertainment/2018/05/14/tim-allen-shares-first-teaser-for-last-man-standing-season-7.html|accessdate=16 May 2018|agency=Fox News|date=15 May 2018}} He is also known as the voice of [[Buzz Lightyear]] in the ''[[Toy Story franchise]]'' since 1995, and for playing Scott Calvin and [[Santa Claus]] in [[The Santa Clause (film series)|''The Santa Clause'' film trilogy]] (1994–2006). Allen's other films include ''[[For Richer or Poorer]]'' (1997), ''[[Jungle 2 Jungle]]'' (1997), ''[[Galaxy Quest]]'' (1999), ''[[Big Trouble (2002 film)|Big Trouble]]'' (2002), ''[[Christmas with the Kranks]]'' (2004), ''[[The Shaggy Dog (2006 film)|The Shaggy Dog]]'' (2006), ''[[Wild Hogs]]'' (2007), ''[[Redbelt]]'' (2008), and ''[[Crazy on the Outside]]'' (2010). ==Early life== Allen was born in [[Denver]], Colorado, to Martha Katherine (née Fox), a community-service worker, and Gerald M. Dick, a [[real estate]] agent.Stated in interview on ''[[Inside the Actors Studio]]''{{cite news|first=Dotson|last=Rader|url=http://www.timallen.com/actor/press_archive/intimacy.php|title=Facing My Fear of Intimacy|magazine=Parade|date=October 27, 2002|via=timallen.com}} He is the third oldest of five brothers. His father died in a car accident, colliding with a drunk driver when Allen was eleven.{{cite web|url=https://movies.yahoo.com/movie/contributor/1800021848/bio|title=Tim Allen Biography|publisher=Yahoo! Movies}} Two years later, his mother married her high school sweetheart, a business executive, and moved with her six children to [[Birmingham, Michigan]], a suburb of [[Detroit, Michigan|Detroit]], to be with her new husband and his three children. Allen attended [[Seaholm High School]] in Birmingham, where he was in theater and music classes (resulting in his love of classical piano). He then attended [[Central Michigan University]] before transferring to [[Western Michigan University]] in 1974.{{cite web|title=WMU awards Tim Allen honorary degree|url=http://www.wmich.edu/wmu/news/1998/9806/9798-338.html| publisher=Western Michigan University| accessdate=June 12, 2010|date=June 27, 1998}} At Western Michigan, Allen worked at the student radio station [[WIDR]] and received a [[Bachelor of Science]] degree in communications specializing in radio and television production in 1976 with a split minor in philosophy and design.{{cite web|title=Tim Allen: Actor: Biography|url=http://www.timallen.com/actor/bio.php|website=timAllen.com |accessdate=June 12, 2010}} In 1998, Western Michigan awarded Allen an honorary Fine Arts degree and the Distinguished Alumni Award. == Career == [[File:Tim Allen (2076447441).jpg|thumb|right|Allen at the 45th Emmy Awards]] Allen started his career as a comedian in 1975. On a dare from one of his friends, he participated in a comedy night at [[Mark Ridley's Comedy Castle]] in [[Royal Oak, Michigan|Royal Oak]], a suburb of Detroit. While in Detroit he began to get recognition appearing in local television commercials and appearing on cable comedy shows such as Gary Thison's ''Some Semblance of Sanity''. He moved to Los Angeles and became a regular performer at [[The Comedy Store]]. He began to do stand-up appearances on late-night talk shows and specials on record and film. Despite his admitted limited acting range (he once told a magazine his range as an actor is "strictly limited. I can only play a part if I can draw on personal experience, and that well can go dry pretty quickly"),{{cite news |title= Tim Allen: 'Home' is where the heart is |date= April–May 1996 |url= http://www.midtod.com/9603/allen.phtml |magazine= Midwest Today Magazine |accessdate= May 31, 2013}} Allen rose to fame in acting with the [[American Broadcasting Corporation|ABC]] [[sitcom]] ''[[Home Improvement (TV series)|Home Improvement]]'' (1991–1999) produced for ABC by Wind Dancer Productions, a company he co-founded with producer [[Carmen Finestra]]. Allen played the main character [[Tim Taylor (character)|Tim "The Tool-Man" Taylor]]. In November 1994, he simultaneously starred in the highest-grossing film ([[Disney]]'s ''[[The Santa Clause]]''), topped the ''New York Times'' best-seller list with his book ''Don't Stand Too Close to a Naked Man'', and appeared in the top rated television series (''Home Improvement'') within the span of one week. ''Home Improvement'' ran until 1999, for which he was paid US$1.25 million per episode. In 1995, Allen provided the voice of [[Buzz Lightyear]] in the Disney/[[Pixar]] blockbuster ''[[Toy Story]]''. In 1997, he starred in the family comedy ''[[Jungle 2 Jungle]]'' from Disney. The next year he returned to voice Buzz Lightyear in ''[[Toy Story 2]]'' which was a financial and critical hit. Also, in 1999 he starred in the sci-fi parody ''[[Galaxy Quest]]'' alongside [[Sigourney Weaver]], [[Alan Rickman]], and [[Sam Rockwell]]. In 2002, he reprised his role as Scott Calvin in ''[[The Santa Clause 2]]''. Two years later, he starred as Luther Krank in ''[[Christmas with the Kranks]]''. In 2006, ''[[Zoom (2006 film)|Zoom]]'' was released, starring Allen as Jack Shepard. The same year, he also starred in ''[[The Shaggy Dog (2006 film)|The Shaggy Dog]]'' and ''[[The Santa Clause 3]]''. [[File:Last Man Standing Cast - Men.png|thumb|right|Allen, with co-stars [[Hector Elizondo]] and [[Christoph Sanders]], on the set of ''Last Man Standing'']] Allen began narrating the "[[Pure Michigan]]" television and radio commercials for the "Travel Michigan" agency. These commercials can be seen and heard throughout the [[Midwestern United States|Midwest]] and began airing nationally in 2009.{{cite web|title=Tim Allen and Pure Michigan|url=http://www.michigan.org/blog/pure-michigan-ads/pure-michigan-tim-allen/|website=michigan.org|accessdate=March 23, 2015}} In December 2009, he started a preview tour of ''[[Crazy on the Outside]]'', a film that debuted in January 2010. Allen accompanied the film, helping promote it with a series of stand-up acts beforehand. During the performances, he told audiences that he planned a 2010 comedy tour. Allen also directed the film, marking his film directorial debut.{{cite web|url = http://www.timallen.com/?xpt=1|title = Stand Up and Show It Tour Dates| publisher=TimAllen.com}} Allen hosted the [[TV Land Award|8th Annual TV Land Awards]] on April 25, 2010.{{cite news|url=http://news-briefs.ew.com/2010/03/30/tim-allen-to-host-tv-land-awards/|title=Tim Allen to Host TV Land Awards|last=Ward|first=Kate |date=March 30, 2010|work=News Briefs| publisher=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|accessdate=March 31, 2010}} That same year, he became the official voice of the [[Chevrolet Cruze]], narrating commercials for the vehicle, and he became the voice of Campbell Soup's "It's Amazing What Soup Can Do" campaign.{{cite news| url=http://www.brandchannel.com/home/post/2010/09/07/Campbell-Soup-Repositions.aspx| title=Campbell's Soup Shirks Canned Cool for Wholesome Warmth| last=Brady| first=Shirley| date=September 7, 2010| work=brandchannel| accessdate=January 23, 2011| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100913012153/http://www.brandchannel.com/home/post/2010/09/07/Campbell-Soup-Repositions.aspx| archivedate=September 13, 2010| df=mdy-all}} Allen returned to ABC with the sitcom ''[[Last Man Standing (U.S. TV series)|Last Man Standing]]'' (2011–2017). He played the role of Mike Baxter, a [[Conservatism in the United States|conservative]] father fighting for his manhood in a house filled with women.{{cite web|url= http://www.tvguide.com/News/Tim-Allen-ABC-1029665.aspx|title=Tim Allen to Join ABC's The Last Days of Man |website= tvguide.com| accessdate=February 23, 2011}} The character is loosely based on his own life, as a Republican father of three girls.{{cite web|url=http://freebeacon.com/culture/tim-allen-im-what-they-call-fiscal-conservative/| title=Tim Allen: 'I'm What They Call Fiscal Conservative' - Washington Free Beacon| work=Washington Free Beacon}} After six seasons, the show was cancelled in May 2017. ABC Entertainment Chief [[Channing Dungey]] denied claims of political bias against Allen, explaining that the network simply could not accommodate the program on their schedule.{{cite web|title=ABC Is Reiterating Its Claim That 'Last Man Standing' Wasn't Canceled Because Of Tim Allen's Politics|url=https://moviepilot.com/p/abc-chief-repeats-last-man-standing-not-canceled-tim-allen-politics/4342445|website=MoviePilot.com|publisher=[[Moviepilot]]|accessdate=September 6, 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170906225533/https://moviepilot.com/p/abc-chief-repeats-last-man-standing-not-canceled-tim-allen-politics/4342445|archivedate=September 6, 2017|df=mdy-all}} Shortly before the cancellation of ''Last Man Standing'', Allen had been announced as part of the cast of the [[Netflix]] original comedy film ''[[El Camino Christmas]]'' (2017).{{cite web|last1=Busch|first1=Anita|title=‘Hidden Figures’ Filmmaker Ted Melfi Lines Up Strong Ensemble Cast For ‘El Camino Christmas’ At Netflix|url=http://deadline.com/2017/04/tim-allen-vincent-donofrio-el-camino-christmas-ted-melfi-hidden-figures-filmmaker-netflix-1202076503/|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|accessdate=September 6, 2017}} == Personal life == Allen was raised as an [[Episcopal Church in the United States of America|Episcopalian]]. He was married to Laura Deibel from April 7, 1984, until they [[Marital separation|legally separated]] in 1999. Their [[divorce]] was finalized in 2003.{{cite news|url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qn4188/is_20030315/ai_n11382377/ |title=Actor Tim Allen and wife settle their divorce | Deseret News (Salt Lake City) Newspaper | Find Articles at BNET |publisher=Findarticles.com |date=March 15, 2003 |accessdate=September 2, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151102080213/http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qn4188/is_20030315/ai_n11382377/ |archivedate=November 2, 2015 |df= }} They have one daughter. Allen married actress [[Jane Hajduk]] on October 7, 2006, in a small private ceremony in [[Grand Lake, Colorado]]. They had dated for five years.{{cite web|url = http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,1544253,00.html|title = Tim Allen Marries Longtime Girlfriend Jane Hajduk|publisher = People.com|date = October 9, 2006}} In March 2009, their daughter Elizabeth was born.{{cite news|url = http://www.nydailynews.com/gossip/2009/03/30/2009-03-30_its_a_girl_for_tim_allen_wife_jane_hajdu.html|title = It's a girl for Tim Allen, wife Jane Hajduk|agency = NYDailyNews.com|date = March 30, 2009| location=New York| work=Daily News| first=Issie| last=Lapowsky}} In September 2014, Allen, like his character Mike Baxter in ''[[Last Man Standing (U.S. TV series)|Last Man Standing]]'', became a licensed [[amateur radio]] operator under the callsign KK6OTD.{{cite web|url=http://wireless2.fcc.gov/UlsApp/UlsSearch/license.jsp?licKey=3628906| title=ULS License – Amateur License – KK6OTD – Dick, Tim| work=fcc.gov}}{{cite news|url=http://www.arrl.org/news/actor-tim-allen-gets-his-ham-ticket-for-real| publisher=[[ARRL]]| title=Actor Tim Allen Gets His Ham Ticket For Real| date=September 30, 2014}} Also like his character, Allen is a [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]].{{cite web|url=http://www.foxnews.com/entertainment/2015/08/04/last-man-standing-star-tim-allen-were-going-to-drill-hillary/| title='Last Man Standing' star Tim Allen: 'We're going to drill Hillary'| author=Paulette Cohn| work=Fox News}} He has appeared on [[Hannity|Sean Hannity's show]]{{cite web|url=http://www.newsbusters.org/blogs/nb/curtis-houck/2015/09/26/tim-allen-sean-hannity-slam-feds-debt-political-correctness| title=Tim Allen, Sean Hannity Slam Feds on Debt, Political Correctness, Spending| work=NewsBusters}} and announced support for [[John Kasich]],{{cite web| url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2015/aug/5/tim-allen-backs-john-kasich-hes-a-republican-a-dem/| title=Tim Allen backs John Kasich: 'He's a Republican a Democrat could vote for' - Washington Times| work=The Washingtion Times}} and later [[Donald Trump]], in the [[United States presidential election, 2016|2016 presidential election]].{{cite news|last1=France-Presse|first1=Agence|title=ABC denies axing Tim Allen's Last Man Standing over Donald Trump support|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/08/06/abc-denies-axing-tim-allens-last-man-standing-donald-trump-support/|accessdate=7 August 2017|agency=Telegraph}} ==Legal issues== On October 2, 1978, Allen was arrested in the [[Kalamazoo/Battle Creek International Airport]] for possession of over {{convert|650|g|lb}} of [[cocaine]]. He subsequently pleaded guilty to drug trafficking charges and [[Informant|provided the names of other dealers]] in exchange for a sentence of three to seven years rather than a possible [[life imprisonment]]. He was paroled on June 12, 1981, after serving two years and four months in [[Federal Correctional Institution, Sandstone]] in [[Sandstone, Minnesota]].{{cite web|url = http://www.mackinac.org/article.aspx?ID=35| title = 650-Lifer Punishment Is a Crime| publisher = Mackinac Center for Public Policy| author=Pratt, Monica| date=March 3, 1997|accessdate=January 9, 2010}}{{cite news |last= Connelly |first= Chris |title= Broken Home |magazine= Ladies' Home Journal |date= April 1997|url= http://www.timallen.com/actor/press_archive/ladies.php| via= timallen.com |accessdate= September 25, 2010}}{{cite web|title=Tim Allen: From Convicted Drug Dealer to Hollywood Star| url=http://investigation.discovery.com/investigation/where-now/allen/tim-allen.html| work=Investigation Discovery| publisher=Discovery| accessdate=September 25, 2010| first=Gary C. |last= King}} [[File:US Navy 100722-N-7705S-096 Actor Tim Allen talks with Sailors aboard the Los Angeles-class attack submarine USS Scranton (SSN 756) during a tour of the ship.jpg| thumb|right| Allen with members of the United States Navy, 2010.]] In 1997, Allen was arrested for [[DUI]] in [[Birmingham, Michigan]]. At the time, his [[blood alcohol content]] was 0.15, nearly double the legal limit in Michigan.{{cite news| url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/1998/04/17/entertainment/main7494.shtml| title=Tim Allen Enters Rehab Clinic| work=[[CBS News]]| publisher=[[CBS Interactive]]| date=April 17, 1998| accessdate=January 21, 2010}} He was sentenced to one-year probation. He entered a rehabilitation clinic for alcohol abuse as part of his court obligation.{{cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/archives/gossip/1998/04/17/1998-04-17_self_-__improvement___tim_al.html |title=Self – 'Improvement': Tim Allen Enters Rehab |last1=Sutton |first1=Larry |first2=Marcus |last2=Baram |date=April 17, 1998 |newspaper=[[Daily News (New York)|New York Daily News]] |accessdate=February 24, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090707192819/http://www.nydailynews.com/archives/gossip/1998/04/17/1998-04-17_self_-__improvement___tim_al.html |archivedate=July 7, 2009 |df= }} == Filmography == === Film === {| class="wikitable" |- !
